Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: WormNet2: Assembling the Annelid Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The more than 16,000 recognized species of annelid worms exhibit immense morphological diversity and include such distinct groups as fireworms, earthworms, bloodworms, and leeches. As sediment feeders, scavengers, and predators, annelids occupy terrestrial and aquatic habitats worldwide and are the most abundant fauna (larger than 1 millimeter) in the deep sea, Earth's most extensive habitat. Annelids have economic importance as bait, pests, invasive species (e.g., oyster borers) and ecosystem engineers. Nonetheless, many fundamental questions about annelids remain unresolved because knowledge of their diversity and evolutionary history is lacking. To fill this gap, this international project will assemble the annelid family tree using a large-scale, multi-tiered approach. The oldest relationships will be examined with high-throughput DNA genome sequencing techniques. Recent relationships will be resolved with multi-gene DNA approaches and a community-based sequencing service that will examine approximately 3000 species.

As one of the few segmented phyla, annelids are integral to understanding animal evolution. This project has significant interdisciplinary implications in fields such as developmental biology, paleontology, marine biology, physiology and evolution. Specimens, data, and educational resources will be publicly available. Extensive human resource development includes training more than 25 undergraduates, 5 graduate students and 4 postdoctoral researchers at four institutions, and recruitment of underrepresented groups. K-12 outreach will foster broad scientific participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the umbrella of the collaborative grant “WormNet II: Assembling the Annelid Tree of Life”, my lab at Texas A&M University at Galveston conducted a “Community Sequencing Project” which fostered collaborations with annelid researchers throughout the world. The primary goal of this project was to encourage and enable annelid taxonomists to apply integrative approaches of morphology, DNA sequencing and other data sources (e.g. ecology, development), as applicable, to resolve evolutionary relationships among closely related annelid species, including cases of cryptic species (species which are morphologically indistinguishable, but form distinct genetic lineages). The initiative resulted in numerous collaborative projects with researchers from at least six different countries. While other groups in the WormNet II team focused on inhabitants of terrestrial and freshwater habitats, my group processed primarily marine annelids. We routinely sequenced a 650 base pair fragment of the mitochondrial gene for cytochrome c oxidase subunit I, the most commonly used marker for “DNA barcoding” (a method for identifying species by their unique, species-specific DNA sequence in this marker). Additional gene regions were sequenced whenever necessary, depending on the particular question. We have worked on representatives of at least ten different traditionally recognized annelid families, spanning a large variety of habitats. Examples include: Hermodice carunculata (family Amphinomidae), a species known to consume live corals and possibly transmit coral pathogens and to cause skin irritations in humans; Archinome species (Amphinomidae) which inhabit deep sea hydrothermal vents; Palolo worms (Palola spp.) (Eunicidae) which undergo cycles of mass spawning and have great cultural significance in many Pacific Island locations; Platynereis species (Nereididae) which inhabit shallow water carbon dioxide vents in the Mediterranean Sea and are model species for spiralian development; species of Flabelligeridae which inhabit anchialine caves; Capitella species (Capitellidae) which are often regarded as bioindicators for sediment pollution and are model species for developmental biology; Phascolosoma species (Sipuncula) which, despite their long-lived larval stages, tend to show a high degree of genetic divergence among geographically separated populations. Field collections for this grant were conducted on the US east, west and Gulf of Mexico coasts as well as in Brazil, Panama, South Africa, Far East Russia and Australia. We have found that in most taxa genetic diversity is significantly higher than would be expected based on the morphological diversity. Genetic divergences can sometimes even be observed on a very small geographic scale, for example around the carbon dioxide vents in the Mediterranean Sea where the worms in the vent fields are starkly different from individuals found right outside the vents. On the other side of the spectrum, the bearded fireworm, Hermodice carunculata, is genetically quite uniform throughout its wide distribution range in the Atlantic and its adjacent basins. 

The project has resulted in 13 peer-reviewed publications over the funding period. All sequence data that have led to publications have been made publicly available through the GenBank at the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). Voucher specimens have been deposited at the Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History. One postdoctoral researcher, eight graduate students and at least 10 undergraduate students were trained in methods of DNA extraction, amplification and sequencing as well as morphological and taxonomic work on annelids. Public outreach activities included a 12-day “Training in Tropical Taxonomy” course at the Bocas del Toro Field station of the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, a 2.5-day workshop with the Florida Association of Benthologists in 2016, a blog generated during a research cruise on the “R/V Cape Hatteras” off the coast of South Carolina in 2011, several seminars on university campuses and public presentations.
